Description: Mould-made disc-shaped scaraboid in glazed composition; slightly domed and plain back with straight sides; underside decorated with incised or stamped (?) decoration consisting of lion walking to right and turning head to look backwards, with a long tail raised and small unidentified element to front; pierced through diameter; remains of yellow glaze within motif; yellow core of rough texture; very eroded.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Scarabs and scaraboids with a lion motif depicted on the base belong to a standard group produced at the “Scarab Factory” (on its various productions, see Webb forthcoming). Petrie illustrated a number of different versions (Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVII, 34-45, see especially no. 35 for this piece). This scaraboid belongs to a type which was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area and Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 93, 95-96, type XXVIII A). Only scarabs are mentioned in Gorton typology for the specific motif displayed on this scaraboid (Gorton 1996, 95, subtype A73-88). This piece is mentioned in her work with a different description (Gorton 1996, 100, A204). Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.) forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum, 16th –17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p.100, Type XXVIII A204) (wrong description)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OD.007) (phase 3)
